summary:
I haven't been diagnosed with depression. I try to stay happy, preferring that over being sad, and my kids really keep me going and sane, especially when they greet me from school. However, I definitely have my days, especially when I don't get enough sleep. When I'm not well-rested, I become irritated, tired, and lazy, feeling like I just want to lay down and get the rest I need. My job as a bus operator is very stressful, so getting good rest is crucial for me to handle it.

Life as a single parent is hard and can be expensive, but I work to keep food in the house and support my kids the best way I can. I also experience a lot of frustration, particularly with my oldest daughter's situation. It's like talking to a wall sometimes, and it's frustrating that she's not hearing me, even though I'm trying to help her make changes to better her life. I've also had a lot of deaths around me, which is part of life experience.

To cope, I find peace in things like reading, taking long walks, hot baths, meditating, or just closing my eyes. I prioritize my rest because I know it helps me manage the stress of my job and daily life. I also believe in learning from mistakes and always trying to better myself, like going back to school now to advance my career.

I've felt depressed for a long time, even before I was diagnosed about three or four years ago. My mood is often down, and it just sucks. I struggle with a lack of energy and interest, and I often want to sleep a lot. Getting a good night's sleep is hard; I couldn't sleep last night because I was just thinking about my situation, like my car payment that was due yesterday. My appetite is uncontrollable; either I don't eat enough or I'm gluttonous and eat the wrong things.

My current situation is really tough; I can't find a job, and that makes me really mad and depressed. I've applied everywhere, from entry-level to management, but nothing. It's hard to survive day by day, just trying to eat. The recent passing of my sister six months ago, and becoming homeless and jobless two weeks ago, have made things even worse. This isn't the first time I've felt this way; 20 years ago, I tried to commit suicide instead of returning to my corporate manager job.

I used to be an extrovert, but lately, I've become quite an introvert and stay to myself. I don't feel as confident, charming, or social anymore. My family is pretty dysfunctional, so I can't depend on them; I just depend on myself. I've found therapy useful in the past, but I don't have health insurance now, so I can't access it. To relax, I meditate and skateboard. Sometimes I just go for a nice sunset skate and meditate on my board, which helps me relax.

summary:
I've been diagnosed with depression, though it's been more minor depression and predominantly anxiety. I've had it off and on all my life, starting with anxiety as a teenager, but it was only formally diagnosed about five or six years ago. My anxiety is what they call free-floating, likely due to a chemical imbalance, not specific triggers.

Currently, my anxiety and depression are under control, and I've been feeling pretty good lately, especially after the holidays. However, sleep has always been a challenge for me; I often wake up in the middle of the night. My husband is a great support; we balance each other out if one of us gets emotional or upset. I also believe therapy is useful. We've been attending group therapy for DBT with our daughter, who also suffers from anxiety, and it's been very helpful for learning strategies to manage our minds and worries.

I love the holidays, particularly Christmas, and during that time, I feel fantastic because everything is quiet, and I'm not stressed with work or projects. I don't tend to get annoyed easily; I prefer to just let things go, as I don't believe it's worth the pain or problems. I also avoid confrontation and arguments. When I'm just tired, I'm simply nostalgic, not irritable.

I usually have no problem getting a good night's sleep. However, if I'm anxious about upcoming deadlines or projects, or worried about being late or making mistakes, that anxiety can keep me up all night to ensure everything is done perfectly. I enjoy being around people; I'm very social and talkative, and I like to do a lot of things like playing bridge and chess, or watching old movies. I'm very proud of my children and find being a parent rewarding, focusing on ensuring they are well taken care of physically, mentally, and spiritually.

I've never been diagnosed with depression or PTSD. My main challenge is this anxiety related to performance and perfectionism, which occasionally affects my sleep. My coping strategies involve letting go of problems I can't fix, avoiding confrontation, and engaging in social activities and hobbies. My parents were great, positive role models, and I have a very big family. My anxiety is primarily triggered by work deadlines and my desire for perfection.

summary:
I was diagnosed with depression when I was about 15, so that's about 17 years ago. My parents were the ones who took me in for treatment, initially thinking I might have ADHD.

Lately, I've been feeling more down than usual, especially since graduating. Losing my 24/7 school routine has made it weird to find ways to be productive and know what to do with my time. It's also been depressing to realize that my intelligence and good grades don't always translate to real-world skills, and there aren't many marine biology jobs in California.

My sleep has been a major struggle. Since I was a kid, I've had trouble falling asleep, but about four years ago, it got really bad. I was only getting about four hours of sleep, sometimes waking up every hour, and I'd wake up feeling like a complete wreck. For the past four years, I've been taking trazodone to help me sleep. When I'm feeling down, it's like I become a complete panicked, anxious wreck. I lose my ability to deal with things, I'm much more likely to lose my temper, and I just can't regulate my moods; I become really volatile. It's actually easier for me to keep track of when I feel really, really bad than when I feel really happy.

I haven't been in therapy for about three years because I wasn't enjoying the relationship with my last therapist, but I still see a psychiatrist for my med checks. I believe therapy can be useful if you have the right therapist, but a bad relationship can be harmful. I know that if I forget to take my medicine, like when I'm on a trip, I can't sleep, and that's when things really start to go downhill.

summary:
I’ve had times in my life where I’ve been severely depressed, though I haven’t gone to a doctor for a diagnosis because I’d rather pull myself out of it before resorting to treatment. A major trigger was after my mother died about four years ago. It had been a long battle for a year that we lost, and I didn't know if I was to blame, even though logically I knew I wasn't. My bottom fell out of my world, sending me into a deep depression.

During that time, I almost got divorced because I just didn't want anything anymore. I became very distant from my husband, pushing everything away. There were times when I couldn't get up, just wanting to stay in bed and sleep all day, or just curl up and die. I also neglected my own health, not taking care of my diabetes, eating horribly, and not taking my insulin properly for about a year before my mother passed. This led to me developing pulmonary embolisms in both lungs, which was a tough fight to recover from.

Currently, I feel very anxious and nervous. I worry a lot about "what ifs," like not finding enough work to pay rent or not being able to keep a semblance of stability in my life. It’s hard work to be stable, and I know that, but the anxiety still creeps in. I also can't think of the last time I felt over joyously happy. Sometimes I feel happy, sometimes not so much, sometimes it's in the middle.

To cope, I've learned that I need someone to take care of to get myself out of bed. My cats were a major motivating factor after my mother died, as they depended on me. Now, I have my family to look after, which makes me go out and do things, even when I want to give up. I try to combat anxiety by getting things done, figuring things out, and making a solid plan. I know it’s a cycle, but I also know that what seems huge on the surface can be chipped away at. I also find that I have to be slightly uncomfortable, or I won't do anything with myself; I'd just be content to hang out all day and stay in bed. My mother and grandmother also instilled in me a sense of confidence and realism, helping me understand that my "downer temperament" is just part of me, but life goes on. I also relax by singing, reading, writing, or just trying to clear my mind, though that doesn't always work.

summary: I'm a little depressed, though I believe everyone experiences some sadness. I'm generally quiet and an introvert, preferring to do activities by myself. When faced with disrespect, I tend to shut down. I often walk away from arguments because they don't settle anything. A major regret and a significant source of pain for me was losing my mother; she was extremely close to me and shaped who I am. Looking back, 2010 years ago I would tell myself not to be so angry and upset all the time about things I can't control, and to relax and not be so hard on myself. I've always felt different, even as a child, sensing that things affected me differently than others. I believe I need to evaluate myself and handle my own problems; I don't feel professional help is for me, even though I know it helps others like PTSD veterans. I've always been someone who tries to manage my own situations. Day by day, I'm working on myself and recently started an exercise program as a solution. When I'm with my best friend, I try to be happy and present a positive situation because I know no one wants to be around a depressed person. Happiness comes and goes for me.

summary:
My best friend sometimes describes me as depressed, and I do experience that sometimes. Lately, I've been feeling anxious, especially in the past week, because I've been trying to find a stable place to live, and it's been taking a long time. When I don't sleep well, which can happen if I'm planning things and wake up in the middle of the night, I become very irritable.

I was diagnosed with PTSD about a year and a half ago. I've often thought about past situations and blamed them for my future, especially when I see certain types of individuals or am in certain settings that remind me of when I was younger and things happened that changed my future plans. Because of this, I used to try to avoid those situations and people.

I still go to therapy, and I believe it helps me. I've noticed I don't worry as much, and it's allowed me to understand that speaking about issues relieves the tension of holding them inside. It was difficult at first to be open about my internal emotions, but now it feels good because I know that communicating helps relieve the stress of trying to figure everything out alone. Often, by speaking about issues, I can come up with better alternative plans just by hearing myself talk.

When I'm alone, I can be very 'inter-minded,' having a lot of thoughts that I keep to myself, and in that mode, I don't really interact with people. However, I can also change modes and interact. To relax, I've recently started doing yoga. When I'm annoyed, I usually try to remain quiet, listen, and think of alternate ways or plans to make the situation better. Being around positive people, listening to music, watching comedy shows, and good food also put me in a good mood. I'm proud that I've become more adaptable and resourceful in different environments and situations as I've gotten older.

I'm feeling a bit tired today. A major challenge for me is raising my son with a disability; it's very hard not knowing how to help him. I've also dealt with a lot of frustration, particularly with my mom, who I feel gets too involved and put me down for wanting to socialize. I love her, but it makes me frustrated, and I hate even having those thoughts.

My sleep schedule is quite early; I go to bed around 8 or 8:30 PM, but then I wake up very early, like 1 or 1:30 AM. I've noticed I can be very moody, irritable, and short-tempered, and a bit more sensitive. I've definitely experienced feelings of guilt, sadness, or depression, especially concerning my son's disability. However, I'm now actively working to deal with these challenges better. I'm finding more avenues and resources to help him, and I'm trying to think more positively, rather than feeling sorry for him or myself, or getting stuck in those guilty, sad, or depressed feelings. When I get frustrated, I sometimes go for a walk or try not to think about it. The last time I felt truly happy was a few weeks ago after I did well in school, which was a big achievement for me after a long time.

summary:
I was diagnosed with depression about a year or so ago. Before that, I just didn't feel well or right, and I couldn't pull myself out of it. My main symptoms were just feeling sad, having a lack of energy, and not feeling motivated or like my usual happy self.

Lately, I've been feeling tired, sad, depressed, and blue. I'm just not happy and don't feel good. It's very hard to cope with this. I find myself staying to myself more and not going out with friends as much as I used to. Getting a good night's sleep is terrible; I simply don't sleep. When I don't sleep well, I feel crazy and distracted, and it's hard for me to cope with things; even easy, mundane tasks become difficult.

I'm in therapy, and while I still don't feel great and haven't noticed many changes, it's good to talk to someone and get things off my chest. I haven't felt truly happy for a while, maybe a month or three or four weeks ago. Part of that was when things were going great with my new boyfriend, but I guess the newness wore off. I've also noticed my mood is attributed to the weather; I don't like cold weather, and whenever it changes, I tend to get down. Being around my kids is one thing that usually puts me in a good mood, and it's always fun getting together with them.

summary:
I was officially diagnosed with depression last October, but I think I've been depressed longer than that. My doctors noticed it when I was being treated for other medical issues. I often think I don't have much reason to live, and I don't really have anybody in my life who I think cares enough about me, even if I was dead. I've kind of lost myself; I used to think I had purpose and that I was enough, but I've lost quite a bit of that.

Lately, I feel overwhelmed and preoccupied, just trying to stay alive and on top of things. I've lost my motivation and find it hard to relax. I used to work out, do yoga, meditate, and exercise, but I don't pursue those outlets anymore. I don't do much anything for fun. A good day for me is just a day without something going wrong. If I get a chance to fall asleep, I don't have a problem, but when I don't sleep well, I'm even more distracted and lackluster.

I used to be proud of my career, but I don't have much of a sense of pride anymore. I'm in nursing, but due to my depression and other health problems, I've had to apply for disability and I'm not working. I'm trying to pull it together and get back a sense of me, and I get inspired every once in a while, but overall, I don't seem to be making much progress. It feels like every time I try to move forward, I get knocked back, and it's exhausting. Murphy's Law has really kicked my ass.

I don't have a therapist, just a nurse practitioner who prescribes medication, and nobody really to talk about psychosocial issues, which sucks. I don't have any support system, nobody. My family history involves abuse and neglect; it's always been dysfunctional. It's been many years since I felt truly happy. I used to be confident, dynamic, and centered, helping people, but now I'm in their shoes and can't seem to help myself.

summary:
I was diagnosed with depression a long time ago, back in 1997. I sought help because I was going through a lot of issues and felt unsafe to myself, which led me to get medication and therapy. I'm not currently in therapy; I stopped about six months ago because I felt my therapist wasn't really challenging me and we kept discussing the same things. However, I do find therapy useful when I connect with a therapist, as it helps me talk about what I'm going through. Through therapy, I've become better at describing my emotions and feelings, and I can now take a step back in situations to react more normally. I also used to bury my emotions and feel bad about myself, so it was helpful to talk to someone non-judgmental.

My symptoms have included feeling hopeless all the time, not having enough energy for things I used to enjoy, and having some concentration issues. I also experience weird, disturbing thoughts that sometimes pop into my mind, and an overall crummy feeling about life. These feelings can be triggered by random moments, problems in my interpersonal life, or even by seeing something on television.

To cope, I listen to music, try to distract myself, and my therapist encouraged me to journal. Lately, I've noticed I've been a bit more withdrawn. My sleep has also been more difficult recently; I have a lot of thoughts at night, so I don't sleep well and wake up frequently. This leaves me groggy and yawning a lot during the day, which my friends sometimes mistake for disinterest. The last time I had a truly good night's sleep was around Christmas when I was with my family in New York, which made me feel really happy and present. Moving to LA a year ago was also pretty difficult, and the transition has left me feeling "half and half okay and not okay."

summary:
I was diagnosed with depression around 1980, after my father, who was a psychiatrist, noticed my symptoms. Back then, I wasn't sleeping well; I'd lay around the house, often waking up at noon, and I lacked focus for getting a job. I remember going to the front door of job interviews but not being able to go inside.

I went to therapy for three years, and it helped me get to a much better place. I learned to see depression like a filter or a pair of sunglasses; I constantly have to try to take those glasses off to double-check if I'm perceiving things accurately or through a depressed viewpoint, and I look for clues about that.

Lately, I feel like I'm slipping back a little bit. I've noticed that unemployed periods or work slowdowns, like the one I'm in now, make it easy for me to fall back into sleeping too late or putting things off because my schedule is too wide open. For me, structure is really important; it helps me get out of bed, be on time, and interact with people, which are all beneficial things for someone who tends to be depressed.

My mind tends to focus on things that are probably not that uplifting, more negative. I find myself thinking about how soldiers in ancient times would have faced battle with crude weapons and no medical help, or watching video clips about crocodile attacks and other "terrible doom type things." I probably shouldn't dwell on those so much.

One of my biggest regrets is not finishing college. I think I was going into depression during my senior year and wasn't coping well, even though I was there for seven years. If I could give myself advice, I'd say I should have sought therapy and also probably some outside help just with getting through finals and the logistics, like getting a car for my art projects.

When upsetting things happen at work, like being blamed for delays or not being backed up by the office, I usually cope by dusting off my resume and looking for other situations that might be better. I'm pretty good at controlling my temper in the moment, but I might vent later.

summary: I was diagnosed with dysthymia, which is a mild, long-term lasting form of depression, in the early 1990s. When I'm feeling the symptoms, I'm irritable, moody, and tired. When I'm not feeling well, I'm airheaded, spacey, and slow, and it's not easy for me to get rid of those symptoms. I honestly can't remember the last time I felt really happy. When I get into an "orbit" state, often triggered by people, my family, or just negative and hostile instigators, I vent and ruminate over the same situation repeatedly. I'm not close at all with my parents and have been estranged. I've learned to stay away from losers and avoid negative people, because trying to change them or give them advice is just a waste of my energy. Looking back, I wish I had kept my room in better order, dated more women, and done a better job of enjoying my nice apartment and my single bachelorhood.

summary:
I've been told I don't have depression, and I don't feel 'down,' nor do I have trouble sleeping. However, I've experienced deep guilt and felt 'less than a human being' because of past selfish actions, particularly those that hurt my marriage. I also carry regret about how my gambling issues ruined my career and affected my marriage. I recognize my past behaviors as 'wrong' and 'selfish,' but deep down, I don't think I'm a bad person; I see my compulsive gambling as an 'illness' or 'obsessive compulsive behavior' I was trying to become healthy from.

My compulsive gambling, which I used as a form of release from tremendous work stress, led to significant financial issues and was devastating to my wife, ultimately leading to our separation. It also ruined a good career. Despite these challenges, I maintain a structured daily life, including living with and helping my mother, which I find very therapeutic. Since my heart attack a few years ago, I've become more easygoing, not letting small things bother me as much.

My primary struggle was compulsive gambling, which I now understand was an 'illness' or 'obsessive compulsive behavior.' To cope, I live 'one day at a time,' focusing on being at peace with myself and having peace of mind daily. My strategies include meditation, reading, and watching TV. I'm diligent about my behavior and routines, knowing what's not right for me and avoiding those things. I try not to focus on the past, instead concentrating on the present and my ongoing recovery. My gambling issues emerged during a period of high work stress for both my wife and me, causing us to grow apart. My friends were shocked when they learned about my issues. I'm currently living with my 82-year-old mother, which provides comfort for her and is therapeutic for me. My recovery from compulsive behavior is an ongoing daily process.

summary: I've experienced periods of feeling blue in the past, and I have a family history of it. While these times were concerning, they weren't debilitating, and I was generally able to function on my own. I sought counseling for these concerns, initially being against therapy, but now I find it very useful for gaining clarity and talking through my thoughts and feelings with an unbiased professional, especially an older woman. I also clearly experience seasonal affective disorder; I feel much happier when the weather is nice and sunny, but I tend to feel dark and blue when it's rainy and cold. To relax and manage stress, I rely on exercise like yoga, walking, going to the gym, or surfing, and sometimes just vegging out on the couch. I've worked on mastering these relaxation skills, especially as I've gotten older. I've also improved my emotional regulation; in my younger years, I was more impulsive and would fly off the handle, but now I think before I speak and reflect more. I do regret not spending more time with my parents before they passed and not spending as much time with my daughter when she was younger.

summary:
I've been feeling really down for about six months now. It started after a major project at work fell through, and since then, it's just been a constant heavy sadness, like a dark cloud hanging over me. I often feel this overwhelming sense of hopelessness and guilt, especially about not being productive or feeling like a burden to my family. Sometimes I just feel numb, and other times I get really irritable, even snapping at my family, which I regret. I've completely lost interest in things I used to love, like reading or hiking; there's just no joy or pleasure in anything anymore.

My daily life has been severely impacted. I have trouble falling asleep, often waking up multiple times during the night, but then I also oversleep significantly, yet still feel completely exhausted. My appetite is gone; I eat very little, sometimes even forgetting to eat at all. I've been isolating myself a lot, cancelling plans with friends because I just don't have the energy to socialize, and I feel like I'm pushing them away. Even basic tasks like showering feel like a monumental effort. I have no energy, struggle to get out of bed, and can't concentrate on anything, especially work, which has caused my productivity to plummet. I've missed a lot of work and I'm worried about losing my job. My family has been trying to help and my partner is worried about me, but it's hard to accept help when I feel this way. I often find myself just staying in bed, watching TV mindlessly, or avoiding responsibilities, and I've been having some really dark thoughts.

summary:
I'm feeling a little pensive and down today. My old life, before I lost my job, weighs on my mind a lot; I miss my friends and relationships and feel like I failed, unable to get back on my feet. Most of my anger is directed inward. I still feel immense guilt about a past relationship that ended badly because I wasn't on the right medication, causing everything to spiral out of control. I dwell on things constantly, taking little details and thinking about them until it drives me crazy. Even things from high school can still make me feel uncomfortable, embarrassed, and ashamed, like I'm right back there.

My sleep isn't great; I'm a very light sleeper, tossing and turning all night, and I'm really starting to feel the effects of not getting enough sleep. I'm also pretty estranged from my family and old friends. My mental state significantly impacted my work, leading to me being laid off after being institutionalized once or twice. It makes me angry that I lost everything due to brain chemistry and inadequate help from previous doctors.

I was diagnosed with depression about three or four years ago, though I was on anxiety medication for years before that. Now, with the right medication, I still get upset and depressed, but I don't completely lose it for days at a time like I used to. For a long time, I coped by drinking to slow my mind down. Now, to manage my thoughts, I have to keep my brain constantly occupied, often doing two things at once, like playing a game on my phone while watching TV. I wish I could just let the thoughts come and deal with them, but I can't yet. These thoughts are triggered by everything – anything I see or hear can connect back to them, and I never get a break.

I go to AA meetings, which has a therapy aspect, and I have a psychiatrist, though I only see her a few times a year to keep my medication coming since I'm unemployed. Saying things out loud, trying to make sense of the mess in my head, is a big step. While the chemical parts of my depression feel more under control now, I'm still dealing with real-world problems like applying for jobs daily and never getting a response, which makes it hard to feel self-sufficient. The last time I felt truly happy was a couple of years ago, when everything was going well, and I felt like a normal person, and I don't know if I'll ever feel that again.

I also admit I'm not the best at controlling my mood and sometimes have outbursts, but I try my best to improve. A past feeling that makes me feel guilty is not having been a better older sister when I was younger, but I'm working to make things better now. Despite any hard things that happen, I believe I'll get through them and I always try to smile and be happy, striving to be the best person I can be every day. Even on rough days, I make sure not to take it out on anyone. To relax, I love reading a good book to get my mind going, and I also enjoy camping and being out in nature.

summary:
I've been feeling incredibly down, like a heavy cloud is constantly over me. It's more than just sadness; it's a profound lack of joy, even in things I used to love. I often feel numb, but then overwhelming sadness can hit me. There's a lot of guilt too, for not being able to just 'snap out of it' or be there for my loved ones. Sometimes I feel completely hopeless about things ever getting better, and I can be quite irritable.

This feeling has really impacted my daily life. My sleep is a mess – I struggle to fall asleep, wake up early, and still feel exhausted. My appetite changes; sometimes I eat too much, other times nothing at all, and food just doesn't taste good. I have zero motivation for anything. It's incredibly hard to even get out of bed or do basic tasks like showering. I've withdrawn from friends and family, avoiding calls and cancelling plans because I feel like such a burden. My work is suffering because I can't focus, and I'm constantly tired.

I find myself just lying in bed, staring at the ceiling a lot. I try to push through, but it truly feels like I'm walking through mud. This has been going on for months now; it started subtly a while ago and has just gotten worse.

summary:
Lately, I've been feeling pretty crappy, like there's no way out of my current situation. No matter what I do, things don't seem to get any better, especially with not getting the kind of work I want and my money not working out at all. I haven't felt truly happy in a long time; the last time was about eight months ago when I saw my biological mother.

My current living situation, where I care for an elderly woman, creates a lot of anxiety. She's exhausting and utterly depressing to be around. Living with her is probably the hardest thing I've ever done, and I would never choose to do it again. Honestly, if I knew what I was getting into, I don't think I would have said yes. This situation, combined with needing to find financial means to support myself, makes me feel trapped and overwhelmed.

While I can generally sleep through the night, I've had some pretty anxiety-ridden dreams the last couple of weeks, though I can usually fall back asleep. To relax, I like to do yoga, but I don't have the money for it right now. I love to dance, read, and go to the ocean to stare at the waves; that really recharges my battery more than anything else. I also like being with friends, enjoying art, and trying new restaurants. When I'm feeling tense, I sometimes turn on the fish tank screensaver. I've had depression before; I stopped therapy when I was no longer depressed, and then again when I moved to Ireland. I see therapy as a way to work on specific problems and gain tools for life, not as a permanent thing.

summary:
I've been feeling kind of like I'm cruising on a 'nice gray line,' which I actually find stable and comfortable, even if some people might not like it. I believe that everyone experiences depression, happiness, and anger, just on different days and in different ways, and I haven't been diagnosed by a medical professional.

The hectic and chaotic atmosphere of Los Angeles, with its car culture and constant 'grind,' isn't very supportive and can be overwhelming. To escape this, I love traveling to see the world as it truly is, away from the 'man-made image' of the city. I recently found a sense of 'relative sanity' in Los Banos, where I could breathe, hike, farm, and do carpentry without digital distractions, which was truly enjoyable.

When my thoughts get overwhelming, it takes me a long time to remember to breathe and settle down for sleep. To relax and help with this, I make chamomile tea, practice breathing exercises, go through my mantras, and do 'pre-dream therapy work.' Sometimes, if I'm lucky, a nice indica helps me get drowsy. I recently felt guilty about how I handled leaving an apartment and a relationship, wishing I had been more thoughtful about it. My family is important to me; I'm very close with my mom and sister, and while communication with my dad needs work, I connect with him through his art.

summary:
I've been diagnosed with depression, and lately, I've been feeling a little bit upset. My symptoms include feeling depressed, keeping myself locked in, and not talking to anyone. I really wish I had friends and loved ones, and an actual relationship, but I don't.

Sleep is really not that easy for me; it usually takes a few hours to finally get to sleep once I lay down. My social interactions are difficult; I have trouble making new friends and trusting people because of my past. I tend to push people away, and whenever someone gets too involved in my life, I always say or do something to make them want to stay away. I don't really have a relationship with any of my family – we just don't talk.

To cope, I try to avoid stress. After stopping therapy because I didn't feel they were really listening, I've been looking for alternative means like music and forcing myself to go to different social related events. A significant way I interact is by playing online multiplayer games with avatars and usernames; it's how I have somewhat fun talking to people without them knowing who I really am or even my real name. My ideal weekend often involves playing online games, going to a movie alone, or driving to a new place by myself.

I wish I had a more normal, stable life and a bunch of people I could call friends. I also wish I was a bit healthier, looked better, and had better eyesight. I've had nightmares about my childhood involving my biological father, which started when I was 16. I guess I wish I handled situations differently, especially when I push someone away. I'm trying to trust people a little bit more and let them into my life, even though it's not easy.

summary:
I've been diagnosed as a classic depressive, probably about six years ago. My wife really encouraged me to seek help, initially thinking it would assist with finding work, but for me, it's more about having someone to talk to who understands me.

Lately, I've been feeling very anxious, primarily because of significant financial pressures – I have big bills and not a lot of income. This makes me constantly worried about losing ground, and it's a very uncomfortable position to be in.

When I was first diagnosed, my main symptoms were a lot of trouble with the struggle and a general displeasure with my life. This feeling persists; I can't really recall the last time I felt truly happy. Even small acting gigs, while mildly enjoyable, usually end up being disappointing, and I'm never over-excited with happiness.

My sleep is often affected; I self-medicate to fall asleep, and about half the nights I wake up much earlier than I'd like. If I don't get my usual seven hours, I feel sluggish and not as functional as I'd like to be, though I generally cope pretty well.

Beyond the financial strain, I've also been sleeping separately from my wife for about three years. In terms of coping, I find listening to talk radio, reading, and cooking helpful for relaxation, and therapy is something I look forward to because it provides a space to talk to someone who gets it.

summary:
I've been feeling kind of down lately, frustrated, and just more sad. A big part of why I feel this way is that I don't have a boyfriend and I don't have money. I'm poor, and I don't want to be. It's been over two years since I felt really happy; back then, I didn't have any money problems and was doing fine. Leaving home was a hard decision, and I miss it.

My sleep is pretty good now that my roommates don't have the TV on, but when I don't sleep well, I'm tired and lazier during the day. My financial situation really impacts my life. It's hard when you don't have enough money to get your own place, so I have to live with roommates. It's too expensive here. I tried to find work in LA. I even had to move out of a place recently because my roommate had marijuana plants.

To relax, I watch funny TV shows like Big Bang Theory or funny movies. Sometimes, when I'm feeling tense, I turn on the fish tank screensaver. I'm proud that I persevere. I also try to remember advice from a mentor I had a few years ago, who taught me to never complain and be thankful for everything I have. I've been trying to save money, and I'd tell my younger self not to spend so much because I'll need it in the future.

My current feelings of sadness and frustration have been going on for over two years. The lack of money and not having a boyfriend are big reasons for how I feel. I haven't been diagnosed with depression.

I can also be kind of lazy and procrastinate, often putting things off until they're due or even after, and I wish I had a better work ethic. My current writing work isn't really that interesting to me, as I'd prefer to write what I want. Sometimes, when people write negative comments about my work online, it makes me feel bad. To relax or when I'm feeling tense, I'll lay down, try some deep breathing, or do something mind-numbing like watching TV, or even turn on a fish tank screensaver. Hanging out with my friends, watching good movies, or listening to music usually puts me in a good mood. My grandparents basically raised me, and I'm close with them, as well as my friends, who describe me as funny, easy to get along with, and caring. I feel satisfied with myself and my place in the world. These feelings and behaviors aren't new; they've been the same as ever, and I haven't been diagnosed with depression.

The fact that I learned several languages. The fact that I've been able to maintain really long relationships with my friends. Okay, I think I've asked everything on YouTube. summary:
I haven't been diagnosed with depression, but lately, I've been feeling stressed and worried. Sometimes I have disturbing thoughts, though I'm not aware of what triggers them. I feel guilty about not generating as much income as I need to right now, as I'm having significant struggles in my career financially. I regret not taking my career seriously earlier, as it's much harder now. I'm working very hard to remedy this, doing many things to generate more money and looking for other ways to earn income outside my career.

My past includes a traumatic experience of being raped. I also made the very difficult decision to not have a child, which was due to financial burden and the father not wanting the child. My relationship with my father is not great; he's mostly been in and out of my life, and I still wish that could be remedied somehow.

I usually get a good night's sleep almost every night, but if I don't sleep well, I'm grumpy and lethargic in the morning. To relax, I typically stay home and watch a movie in bed. I tend to be shy initially, but I become much more outgoing as I get to know people. Being a parent, especially to my stepchildren, is challenging, and I sometimes struggle with how much to get involved. I wish I could be a little bit stronger and definitely more assertive.

Despite these challenges, I have lots of friends and family here, and I consider myself a wonderful, loyal, honest, and caring friend who loves deeply. I recently felt absolutely fantastic, happy, relaxed, and free on a holiday in Cancun, like I didn't have a care in the world temporarily. Spending time with my stepchildren at the pier and making them happy was also one of the best times in the last few weeks.

summary:
I've been feeling really low for about six months now. It started gradually after a period of high stress at work and a personal loss. My mood is a deep sadness, an emptiness, and I've lost interest in almost everything I used to enjoy. There's a constant feeling of guilt, especially about not being productive or feeling like a burden. Hopelessness often sets in, making it feel like there's no way out, and sometimes I just feel numb or overwhelmingly exhausted. I've also noticed I'm more irritable, snapping at people easily.

Daily life is a huge struggle. I have trouble sleeping, sometimes with insomnia, other times I sleep too much. My appetite has changed, either not eating much or sometimes overeating. I've been isolating myself, avoiding friends and family because I don't have the energy to socialize, and it's hard to pretend I'm okay. Motivation is non-existent; it's incredibly hard to get out of bed, and basic tasks like showering or getting dressed feel overwhelming. My work performance has suffered significantly, with missed deadlines and calling in sick because I can't focus.

Physically, I'm constantly fatigued and lack energy, and I've experienced physical aches like headaches and stomach issues. My concentration is poor, and I often feel like I have brain fog. My main coping strategy is just trying to get through each day, sometimes just lying in bed or trying to distract myself with TV, though it doesn't really help. I've started seeing a therapist a couple of months ago, and my partner and family have been very supportive, trying to help me, but it's still incredibly difficult.

summary:
I was diagnosed with depression over five years ago. What really got me into it was a deep lack of motivation, and my symptoms mirrored what depression is like. I experienced a significant loss of appetite and just didn't want to do anything. Socially, it was tough; I didn't want to be around people at all and had a fear of social situations. These were the main four or five symptoms I dealt with. My best friend would even describe me as sad sometimes.

I'm not in therapy anymore. I stopped because I felt like I'd moved past a chapter where doctors were experimenting with drugs for my health. Instead, I chose an alternative route, focusing on juicing more and trying to understand what my body needed, often with help from the internet and nutrition experts. I do believe therapy is useful though, as it helps you look inward and readjust to problems before they build up.

Lately, I've been feeling much better than I have in a long time, which I attribute to a transition in my diet, specifically incorporating more raw fruits and vegetables. This change, inspired by raw food educators and detox therapy experts, feels like it's helping to loosen accumulated toxins from past unhealthy choices. It's a daily process to listen to my inner conscious over my brain's cravings for things like caffeine and sugar, and it's very hard. When I get really upset, controlling my hunger can be a problem, and I have to work to calm myself down. Sometimes I just can't stop eating. I've learned to control it more now. I also find relaxation in tea and eating. I feel guilty about not supporting my friends as much with their career choices.

summary: I have not been diagnosed with depression. I'm generally pretty happy and feel pretty good all the time, maintaining an even keel. Significant unhappiness only occurs when something devastating happens, like someone I know getting cancer or dying. I don't really feel guilty about any decisions I've made. I go to sleep easily when I'm tired. I feel pretty good, energetic, and motivated, especially with my event planning work. To relax and relieve stress, I work out at the gym, which also helps keep my energy levels up. My friend Mojo is a great motivation for me, pushing me to keep writing and doing events.

summary: I generally try to stay on a 'center line' emotionally, as I'm not usually 'too happy.' I experience emotional pain and some spiritual anxiety about my future, especially from my family relationships, which can be difficult and painstaking. I often find myself giving time to others rather than taking it for myself, which has caused me a lot of emotional pain. I also feel guilty about not taking better care of my pet bird. Making hard decisions, like moving forward on a job opportunity, has been difficult because I weigh the potential emotional pain of leaving my family against financial gain. While my sleep is usually pretty good, if I don't sleep well, I can become irritable and unhappy. I consider myself shy and sometimes find it hard to express my own thoughts. When I'm feeling tense, I sometimes turn on a fish tank screensaver or stare at fish tanks to relax. I wish I could be more decisive and had an easier time meeting more people.

summary:
Lately, I've been feeling pretty down on myself and down on life. It's often hard for me to get a good night's sleep; I struggle to fall asleep because there's too much on my mind, like feeling I haven't accomplished enough during the day. I also frequently wake up in the middle of the night, sometimes due to needing the bathroom, and then it's tough to get back to sleep. I'm pretty used to feeling tired and probably look tired most days, but I just push through. When I can, I'll curl up in bed to read, nap, or watch TV, just trying to vegetate.

My current struggles are largely tied to my pending divorce and financial reasons, as I'm unemployed and need to find a job to move on with my life. I really regret not finishing college; I wish I had stayed and gotten my degree. I also worry a lot that I made many mistakes guiding my daughters when they were younger, and now that they're teenagers, I feel it might be too late to fix things. I don't remember good times very well; it's the bad times that stick with me. When asked about feeling truly happy, the only thing I could think of was when my children were born. I don't feel much pride in life, except for my daughters.

I was first diagnosed with depression in my early 20s after a difficult breakup where I felt I was hurting my boyfriend. I didn't understand the feeling then, but I sought out a psychiatrist who prescribed Xanax. Since then, I've had bouts of depression throughout the years, often triggered by relationship issues. The most recent time I was diagnosed and put on medication was about two years ago. I'm not in therapy now because I don't have insurance, but I'd be happy to go if I could. I've realized that a big part of my depression, besides relationships, is tied to not having money; it feels like you can't even try to fix anything without it. I wish I had stuck with a job and built up my expertise and finances earlier in life.

summary:
I've definitely experienced feeling stressed out and depressed. Sometimes, I just want to escape from thinking about anything from the past, present, or future, and playing poker helps me do that; it's almost like a therapy or a drug for me, even though it can be stressful too. I also cope by playing basketball and spending time with friends.

My sleep can be a bit off; for instance, I recently slept almost all day on a day off, which made me feel pretty good, but generally, I don't get as much sleep as I'd like. I went through a really tough period where I got involved with the wrong people, and my life just tumbled downhill. I ended up losing everything – my car, my job, and my apartment. I still wish I had never met certain people or gotten into those unhealthy relationships.

Relationships have been particularly hard for me. I was in a relationship that made me feel stressed out and irritable, and even though I'm still in love with my ex-girlfriend and miss her, the hardest decision I ever made was to stay away because I knew it wasn't healthy. That was incredibly difficult, and it still is. I also feel like I have a constant need to be in a relationship or for sexual activity, which I wish I didn't. I feel like it's almost an addiction, and it keeps me from focusing on other things and getting more done in my life, though I'm working on that.

summary:
I often struggle with my mood. I feel a deep sense of guilt about how things ended with my mom before she passed, wishing I could have been there more. This feeling of being robbed, especially since I grew up without her and then lost her again when I was 18, still lingers with me.

My daily functioning is impacted. For instance, today, if it wasn't for my daughter's birthday party, I probably would have stayed in bed. Sleep is a big challenge; I didn't sleep well last night and often feel groggy. I tend to try to do everything and need to remember to prioritize my own self-care. I also wish I could change my weight.

Despite these struggles, my daughter is my biggest motivation. She gives me the enthusiasm to go the extra mile, to provide for her and ensure she has a good life. She's my heart and my pride and joy. I also find strength in my faith, believing that God is there for me so I don't have to face the world alone. To relax, I enjoy going to the beach, sitting by the waves, and rubbing my toes in the sand, or sometimes I just put on a fishtank screensaver. I've also learned to block out negativity and I don't let what other people think bother me anymore, which used to be an issue. Lately, I've been feeling more confident and positive about being a good parent, even though I haven't been diagnosed with depression.

summary:
I've been feeling really low for a few months now, a profound sadness and emptiness that's hard to shake. Nothing feels good anymore, and there's an overwhelming sense of hopelessness. I also feel a lot of guilt about not being productive and worrying my family. Sometimes I get really irritable and snap at them, which I regret. My mind often races with anxiety, worrying about everything, and I've lost all interest in things I used to enjoy.

This has impacted almost everything. I'm exhausted all the time, either struggling to fall asleep, waking up too early, or just feeling unrefreshed no matter how much I sleep. My appetite is gone; food tastes like ash, and I've lost weight. I've been isolating myself, avoiding calls from friends because it feels like too much effort to pretend to be okay. I have no energy or motivation, making it incredibly hard to get out of bed or even shower. At work, I'm struggling to concentrate, missing deadlines, and my performance is slipping. My house is a mess because I can't keep up with chores.

Beyond the low mood, I experience racing thoughts, and sometimes physical aches like headaches and stomachaches. I try to push through, or sometimes just lie in bed or watch TV to distract myself, but it doesn't really help.

This started gradually a few months ago, triggered by stress at work and a breakup. My family and partner are trying to be supportive, but I often feel like a burden to them. I've had similar feelings before, but never this severe or long-lasting.

summary:
Lately, I've been feeling very one-note, like there are no extreme highs or lows, just a kind of flat emotional land. Over the past few years, I've noticed a progressive change in myself; I've become much more seclusive and reserved, not very outgoing at all.

Sleep has become a consistent problem. I can't seem to stay asleep, waking up like clockwork by 7:30 or 8:00 AM every single day, no matter when I go to bed. This was never an issue before, but now I can't remember the last time I slept past 8:30 AM. It makes me feel a lot more tired during the day, though I'm so used to it now that it doesn't really change my mood.

I've been diagnosed with anxiety, which once manifested physically as breathing problems, leading me to the hospital. When I'm feeling tense, I sometimes turn on a fish tank screensaver to relax, and I also watch lighthearted reality TV like Bravo shows because I don't need to pay much attention to them. I don't really have a temper, but stress definitely shows in my attitude.

I regret the college I chose, as it created more problems for me than I anticipated. I also had therapy as a kid, but I didn't feel I needed it then and didn't get much out of it. When I'm with my boyfriend's family, especially over holidays, I feel happy because it's a complete vacation where I don't have to worry about bills or what I need to do.

Probably like two nights ago. Wow. Tell me about the last time you felt really happy. That is a hard question. I think in November after I got out of the hospital, I finally had one good day and my friend took me into downtown Chicago and we went to the Sears Tower and got to look over those like big windows that you walk out on and see the city and that was really cool. The trainer said does anyone want to help him? If someone helps him, you have to do half each. No one wanted to help him and then I just decided to start doing push-ups with him. summary:
I've been feeling really low for about six months now; it started gradually after some stress at work and a breakup about seven months ago. There's this persistent sadness that just won't lift, an overwhelming sense of hopelessness, and a lot of guilt about not being productive or feeling like a burden to my family. Sometimes I even feel a numbness, like I can't feel anything at all, and I've noticed I'm more irritable, snapping at my family. I often feel worthless and anxious about the future and social situations.

My daily life has been significantly impacted. I have trouble falling asleep because my mind races, and I wake up multiple times during the night with anxiety. Even when I oversleep for 10-12 hours, my sleep isn't restorative, and I'm still exhausted. I've lost my appetite; food tastes bland, and I have to force myself to eat. I've been withdrawing from friends and family, cancelling plans because it feels like too much effort to pretend to be okay, preferring to be alone. I have no energy, it's hard to get out of bed, and I struggle with basic tasks like showering or getting dressed. I can't focus at work, my productivity has plummeted, and I've lost interest in hobbies I used to love, like reading and hiking.

I'm just trying to get through each day. Sometimes I lie in bed staring at the ceiling, or try to distract myself with TV, though it doesn't really help. My sister is trying to be supportive, and I do try to talk to her sometimes, but I worry about burdening her. I had similar feelings a few years ago, but it wasn't this intense or long-lasting, which is why I finally decided to seek help.

summary:
I was diagnosed with depression back in 2004. I sought help because my life had become so stressful to the point where I felt I had to do something, or end something. I still go to therapy now, and I find it useful as a good sounding board, especially with medication. Since starting therapy, I've noticed a lot of changes; I've been more focused and more hopeful, though it's still been a bit of a struggle.

Lately, I've been feeling a little anxious, mainly due to the stress and new expenses from moving into a new apartment. When it comes to happiness, I can feel really happy by some occurrence, but I can't think of anything right now just like that, and then I go back to how I was feeling. If something comes to me unexpectedly, or if things go right for a change and continue to go right as opposed to things going wrong all the time, that makes me happy. I can't think of anything I've really enjoyed recently.

A major symptom for me is sleep. I don't get a good night's sleep or sleep at all unless I take medication; I'll be up all night, or even for days, if I don't. When I don't sleep well, I become irritable and tired. I also don't have a best friend.

To relax, I listen to music, watch horror movies, and watch my fish. I also like to play tennis, but I haven't been able to lately because I injured my ankle due to anemia, which caused me to get dizzy and fall. I'm waiting for it to heal so I can get back to tennis, as it really relaxes me. I don't feel guilty about anything right now, and I've learned to control my temper over the years. My biggest regret is dropping out of college when I was a pre-law major, due to the stresses involved with my ex-husband. My advice to myself 10 or 20 years ago would be to stay in school, no matter what, and stay the course.

summary: I haven't been diagnosed with depression, and emotionally, I've been feeling good lately, especially since I'm on vacation. While I do struggle with getting a full night's sleep, often waking up a few times throughout the night and sometimes having bad dreams, I don't attribute this to depression. I'm also quite shy and can feel uncomfortable or awkward in social situations, which means I don't have a large group of friends. I wish I were more outgoing. I've learned to control my temper better, but I still sometimes get angry easily, and I felt really bad after a recent argument with my best friend. There's also a very traumatic experience from about 15 years ago that I still think about and wish I could erase from my mind. To relax and deal with stress, I enjoy reading, taking baths, and going to the gym.

summary:
I've been diagnosed with depression, though I don't feel I'm any more depressed than anyone else; everyone has their breaking points. Lately, I feel like I have a wealth of potential and opportunities right within my grasp, but they're just out of my reach, like I need a "connector" to fully realize what I'm capable of. I carry a lot of pain from the bad things I've seen in the world, and I wish I could erase those memories. There's also a deep regret about not getting to know my mom.

My family doesn't really talk, and I'm unsure if my wife truly wants to be with me. I know my daughter loves me, but I also wonder if she wants to be with me. It’s hard when someone says things a certain amount of times, and the tone and belief in their eyes make you question what’s really in their heart.

Sleep just "comes," and when I don't sleep well, I'm just tired and yawning. I regret letting something small and meaningless stop me from going further in school, which I now see as ignorance from being young and foolish.

To relax, I meditate, work out, run, walk, write, and read. My daughter is a huge source of joy; her birthday was the last time I felt truly happy, seeing her have so much fun. I try to guard her from the kind of difficult things I saw as a child. My old foster parents taught me that no matter where you come from, you can always strive to get better.

summary:
My current life situation is quite challenging, and it's been very depressing for me. Since my stroke in February 2012, I've been dealing with nerve damage in my hand and face, and I thought by now it would have gotten a little better, but it hasn't. The biggest source of my depression right now is the long wait for my disability hearing; it will be almost two years since my stroke before I even have a hearing. This uncertainty about my future, especially after working since I was 16, is really hard. I've had to live off my savings, and my daughter, who just finished college, is now having to take care of me while she's still looking for a job. My life feels very much up in the air, and I'm constantly wondering what comes next, so I'm just praying for guidance.

I also carry guilt from a "bad night" that changed my life, and I feel bad about that night. I also feel bad about how my divorce ended, as it was kind of explosive, and I was devastated because I wanted my child to be raised with her father. I think I played a part in keeping a lot of drama going because I was so hurt.

While I try to stay positive and grateful to be alive, and I practice meditation twice a day to calm my body, the ongoing financial strain and uncertainty are a heavy burden. Sometimes it's hard for me to go to sleep, depending on what's going on in my head. My photography, my creative passion, is a great comfort and soothing to my soul, helping me even when I was very ill. I can still shoot with my camera, even though my left hand is diminished in use, which allows me to keep doing my work.

summary:
I've struggled with controlling my emotions, which even led to me getting incarcerated and sent to prison after a physical altercation with an inmate. I often feel frustrated, especially when I put effort into relationships and don't see it reciprocated, though I'm learning that expectations can sometimes set you up for failure. A significant burden for me is the guilt I carry from hurting people emotionally, particularly women in my past, and putting my mother, close friends, and family through things they shouldn't have had to endure. I also feel very lonely.

There are several events I wish I could erase from my memory, like a traumatic experience with my first girlfriend that could have cost me my life, and other incidents like fights, shootouts, getting jumped, and being robbed. These recurring thoughts inhibit me from exploring certain areas of life I'm not comfortable with. I'm not much of an exploring type of person, which might be linked to this. Sometimes, I turn on a fish tank screen saver, a small way to find some calm.

My family relationship used to be rocky when I was growing up, but as I've matured and been through experiences, we've grown closer, and it's pretty decent now. My mother is a huge positive influence; I admire her resilience through economic hardships and raising me at a young age while finishing school and getting her masters, especially since she also battled mental health issues.

summary:
I've experienced feelings of deep remorse, not necessarily guilt, about actions or words said and done in the past. These thoughts, especially about past interpersonal reactions with friends or family, can just hit me out of the blue, making me question why I said or did certain things. Hurting the ones closest to me, like my mom, really sticks.

There have been times when I've felt lethargic, just going through the motions. However, I sleep well each night, getting eight to ten hours, and I often can't wait to get up and start the day, though that feeling can be gradual. I also find myself always regretting not being more productive or efficient with my time each day; I hate wasting time, money, or energy.

I haven't been diagnosed with any psychological acronym. To relax, I swim, and I also find great value in talking with smart, informed, open-minded friends, which gives me a high similar to exercise. My time is usually spent with friends, working on my writing, or exercising.

summary:
I've been experiencing a profound sadness, like a heavy blanket that smothers any joy. It's often accompanied by a deep sense of emptiness and a pervasive feeling of hopelessness, making it hard to see a future where things improve. There's also a lot of guilt about my inability to function and feeling like a burden to others.

Daily life has become incredibly difficult. Getting out of bed feels monumental, and my sleep is completely disrupted – either I can't fall asleep, or I oversleep without feeling rested. My appetite is inconsistent; sometimes I don't eat much, other times I crave unhealthy foods, which just makes me feel worse. I've lost all motivation for activities I once enjoyed, like painting or even simple walks. Socially, I've withdrawn almost completely, finding it hard to respond to messages or meet up with friends and family, even though my sister tries to check in on me. My concentration at work is shot, and I constantly worry about making mistakes.

Physically, I often feel drained, like my limbs are heavy. My thoughts are overwhelmingly negative, constantly replaying past failures or anticipating bad outcomes. I sometimes try to distract myself with TV, but even that feels like too much effort. I've attempted to force myself to go for short walks, and I've also been journaling a bit, which sometimes helps to clear my head, though often it just becomes a list of my worries.

This current episode started about six months ago, after I lost my job, which felt like a significant trigger. I've had similar experiences with depression before, but this one feels particularly heavy and prolonged.

I've been there like three or four times for vacation. How does it compare to LA? Well, it's less stressful. I don't know if it's because I'm on vacation, but I feel more at peace over there than here. Why did you move to LA? Well, my family moved down here for a better life. That was my parents. What are some things you really like about LA? Just the weather and different things that you could do. You could be at the beach or you could go to the mountains. Different variety of things to do. Yeah. What are some things you don't really like about LA? The traffic. Yeah, basically the traffic. That's one of the main things. I see what you mean. I'm sure you can tell by my shoes. I'm not much of a world explorer. Do you travel a lot? Not that much. I've been to New York and Mexico only. Cool. What do you enjoy about traveling? Just seeing new places and finding new locations. Something new. What's one of your most memorable experiences? Like for a trip? Yeah. Well, I've been to Mexico. I've been to the pyramids of what I forgot to call Mexico City. I like finding out about my ancient culture since I'm Mexican. From my genetics, I like to see different things like that. That's great. What did you study at school? Well, at school, I did dropout but I came back and I'm trying to get back into it right now. I'm trying to learn graphic design. How did you decide to do that? Well, I started liking to take pictures, doing different things. I like going into business. I like what the title is about. What's your dream job? I want to have my own business. Either making web pages, just be able to be free and don't be relying on someone else. Just be able to have freedom for myself. Do you consider yourself more shy or outgoing? Outgoing. Why? I just like to be around people, like to get to know people, depending on the person and how I feel around them. Okay. Sometimes when I'm feeling tense, I turn on the fish tank screensaver. Hey, I know it's not Hawaii, but it's the best I've got. What do you do to relax? I like to hear music or do different things like play sports just to unwind. How are you at controlling your temper? Well, I'm getting better at it. What was the last time you argued with someone? What was it about? Well, it was like two days ago. It was something about I needed to pay a bill or something that I had taken care of. But the person, he's more picky about it. He knows how girls are. They want everything right there and then. I have a handle. I have everything there. And they're just bugging. Sometimes they don't give you the space that you need to resolve something. How did you feel in that moment? Well, I felt like I was overwhelmed. I already had it resolved. I just was waiting for a check. It's not on my control, but I already had made the proper arrangements and she's bugging me about it. It's like you're making an argument, a storm in a glass of water. Tell me about a situation that you wish you would handle differently. Well, differently, there's a couple of them, but not so recently because I've been more trying to get my life together. But the decisions I made before in the past, I dropped out of school and doing other different things. What's something you feel guilty about? Guilty? Not that much because not really. Not that I can think right off the top of my head. Okay. Tell me about the hardest decision you've ever had to make. The hardest decision? It's just not on top of my head right now. Okay. Tell me about an event or something that you wish you could erase from your memory. An event? Well, the only things that I remember is when I blacked out or different things like that that I don't remember. But nothing like a particular, only when my brothers died and different things like that. Can you tell me about that? Well, my brother was in gangs and different things and he was getting more into trouble. And it's just not a pleasant memory for me to talk about that much, get into it. Okay. Tell me about your relationship with your family. No, I'm Hispanic. I like to be with my family. And I like to go over there to Mexico too. I have a half sister and my grandpa died. He was over there in Mexico. So I like to have a good relationship with my family. That's good. Who's son of it's been a positive influence in your life? Well, my mom and dad, they always work hard. They always done what they have to do to pay the bills. That's why sometimes I'd be like, you know, running around trying to get everything done, but done correctly, not trying to take the easy way out. How hard is that? It's a little hard because they're, especially here in Los Angeles, there's a lot of different things that you could get into that's not that positive. And it's hard to stay focused on, you know, the correct stuff. How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep? Well, normally I just knock out. It's not that hard. It's like, it takes me like half an hour or 15 minutes. But sometimes I can't even wake up even with the alarm. They have to wake me up. You know, my girl has to wake me up even with the alarm going on. It's like so hard. You know, I just knock out. What are you like when you're dusting off? I do get a little, either I'm angry or I don't feel good and I don't feel with energy. But I still have to know, I know I have to do something, so I still go through with it. How have you been feeling lately? I've been, well, I've been feeling good, you know, doing a little restless, but not that much. I have to do stuff, so I just, you know, put myself to do it no matter how I feel. Have you ever seen any changes in your behavior or thoughts lately? No, nothing out of the ordinary. Have you ever been diagnosed with PTSD? No. Have you been diagnosed with depression? No. Tell me about the last time you felt really happy. The last time I felt happy, that was probably on the weekend that I was, you know, going out with, going out to have some fun and, you know, I was drinking and just relaxing and winding down. Awesome. Mm-hmm. Tell me how you spend your ideal weekend. My ideal weekend is usually with my girl either out or at home, just relax. But nothing else, you know, just be able to relax and unwind with her, you know, either going out somewhere to a nice place or staying at home, but without getting any calls or any interruptions. You know, just be able to turn off the phone and turn off everything and just be with her doing other different things. Yeah. Mm-hmm. How are your best friends around you? Like an outgoing guy, you know, very social, but at the same time I'm reserved depending how I feel with people. I have to, you know, build trust or feel comfortable with them. Uh-huh. What are some things you wish you could change about yourself? Well, I'm changing a lot, you know, like my temper and different things, drinking things. I'm changing a lot of different things so I could get more things done. Tell me about a time when someone made you feel really badly about yourself. Well, there's several, but mostly is when I'm coming from Mexico that they want to demean you even down there. It feels like silly because I went to a store, I was regularly dressed, and I was telling them I wanted to buy something, and then they said that I wasn't belong there. And as soon as they saw my credit card, they kind of changed perspective because they saw the Wells Fargo logo, they know it was American. But they thought it was like, you know, it felt ridiculous to me because you go to a place, you have the money, you ask for something, you can ask for something because you have it, not just to kill their time. Just because they saw a logo of a card, that's how they, you know, it just, it was ridiculous for me. I understand. Is there anything you regret? No. What advice would you give yourself 10 or 20 years ago? Basically, to stay more focused on different things, stay in school, and, you know, don't go, you know, try to control my temper and do different things. Because if I knew what I know now, back then, it would be different. Hmm. What are you most proud of in your life? Well, I did drop out, but I did go back to school and, you know, I did get my high school. And right now I'm in the process of doing other different things. So right now it's getting my high school, getting that together. And right now I'm working to another goal and trying to get, you know, my, either going back to school. So basically getting back to school and finishing the high school, the GED. That's so good to hear. Mm-hmm. Okay. I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me. Okay. You're welcome. Bye. Okay. Stop the recordings. Mm-hmm. I feel like that works like I thought it would.
summary:
I'm doing fine and generally feeling good lately, though I can be a little restless. Sometimes I feel overwhelmed, like when I'm dealing with arguments, and when I wake up, I can feel angry, low on energy, or just not good. While I usually knock out easily when I sleep, it's incredibly hard for me to wake up, even with an alarm; my girlfriend often has to wake me. Despite feeling low on energy, I always push myself to do what needs to be done.

To unwind, I like to listen to music or play sports, and sometimes I'll drink to relax and have fun. I'm actively working on changing things about myself, like controlling my temper and my drinking, so I can get more things done. I regret past decisions, like dropping out of school, but I'm proud that I went back and got my high school diploma, and now I'm working towards new goals like getting back into school for graphic design. I find LA stressful, especially the traffic, and I feel more at peace when I'm in Mexico. I also carry the difficult memory of my brothers dying, which I don't like to talk about much.

summary:
I've been feeling really down lately, like a heavy cloud just hangs over me all the time. There's a profound sadness and a sense of hopelessness, feeling like there's no point to anything. It's more than just sad; it's an emptiness, a void. I don't feel joy in anything, even in things I used to love like my hobbies or seeing friends. I also feel immense guilt, like I'm a burden to everyone, and I cry a lot, sometimes for no reason.

My daily life is terribly affected. I can barely get out of bed most days. My sleep is a mess; either I can't fall asleep, or I sleep for twelve hours and still feel exhausted. My appetite is gone, and I've lost weight because I have to force myself to eat. I've stopped going to work, which makes the guilt even worse. I just isolate myself, and I don't have the energy or desire to respond to my friends, even though they try to reach out. Even simple tasks like showering feel monumental.

These feelings have been building for about six months now, really intensifying after I lost my job. I try to distract myself by watching TV or scrolling on my phone, but it doesn't really help; it just numbs me for a little while. My family is supportive, and my partner tries to help, but I push them away because I don't want to worry them or bring them down with me. It's hard to explain how heavy everything feels, and I just can't open up right now.

summary: I don't really experience depression. I'm basically happy all the time, and I find a lot of satisfaction in making other people happy and being a resource for them. I get many phone calls from people seeking inspiration, and it makes me feel good to offer input and follow up on them. My sleep is very good; any tiredness I feel is due to physical conditions like vitamin B and D deficiencies, not mental issues. I'm quite outgoing when it comes to going places and meeting people, though I can be a bit shy in back-and-forth conversations with strangers. My biggest challenge is my weight, which tends to yo-yo. I see my binging as a 'nervous disorder,' and I'm not happy about being overweight because I have beautiful clothes I can't wear. This is my only regret, not being able to keep the weight off, but it's not related to my overall happiness.

summary:
I've struggled with insomnia my entire life, remembering watching stars from my bed as a child. To sleep, I need to be physically and intellectually tired, which is often hard to achieve, so I frequently stay awake reading until midnight and often wake up around 3 AM.

My mood can fluctuate; for example, yesterday I didn't feel good. It was cloudy and gray, and I just didn't feel like doing the garden planting I'd planned, so I ended up just piddling about and wasting time. Today, however, I feel much more positive and energetic.

I tend to have outbursts of anger at home, especially when things get chaotic or I feel underappreciated. My husband sometimes gets mad at me for being mad, which escalates things, and I might end up walking out or going to my room. I remember one time in the kitchen, feeling immense pressure while making dinner with the kids and my husband bothering me, I actually banged a pot against the stove, making a dent, just to get attention. It was a clear sign I should have walked out sooner and taken deep breaths.

To cope with these outbursts, I've learned to isolate myself for a bit, take deep breaths, and then try to understand why I'm feeling angry or tense so I can verbalize it calmly. It's very hard sometimes, but I'm trying to become calmer and more patient, as patience is what I need to work on most. I also try to meditate, sit quietly, read, or walk my dog to relax. I even find my actual fish tank at home very relaxing.

Parenting is extremely difficult for me because my mother disconnected after my dad died when I was young, so I basically raised myself and didn't have a warm, loving relationship or typical parenting skills modeled for me. I know what not to do, but it's still a challenge. I'm not a warm, fuzzy, cozy kind of mother, though I think I'm a good and creative one. I'm actually more homey when I go camping than when I'm at home, where I tend to be more tense.

I also struggle with procrastination. I start many creative projects with great enthusiasm, get almost finished, and then completely lose interest. Sometimes I think it's because I'm afraid to finish them, which sounds strange, but I'm actively working on completing these projects now. I also regret not following through on career opportunities after the Peace Corps, like getting my master's degree. My ego sometimes got in the way with bad bosses, and I wish I had focused on the job itself rather than my emotional reactions, as it could have led to a more fulfilling and solid career. I've never been diagnosed with depression.
