summary:
I sometimes get depressed or upset, especially when things don't go my way. My goal is to always look at the bright side and count my blessings, no matter how bad things get, and I'm working on it, finding it a little easier now. I can also get irritated, like when I was told my tone of voice was too loud when I just wanted to relax.

A major source of distress for me is the memory of my mother being sick and dependent on oxygen for three years, and seeing her health decline. I chose not to tell her her condition had worsened, and that memory, knowing her symptoms were getting worse without telling her the truth, plagues me the most in my dreams and thoughts. If I could erase that, I would feel better. I try to be grateful I'm alive and focus on my own objectives, not dwelling on negative memories.

I generally sleep well, though sometimes I wake up from nightmares about my mother, but I usually go back to sleep. Financial problems and not getting jobs I feel qualified for can be very frustrating, making me feel like I'm not getting a fair chance. I don't often feel guilty, but if I'm angry when I shouldn't be, especially with my girlfriend, I do feel guilty. I never want to be short with her or use vulgar language.

My girlfriend is a huge positive influence; she calms me down when I'm stressed and is trying to help me be less angry and negative, and to be a more nurturing, positive person. I listen to music to cope. I wish I could stop complaining about negative things and learn to roll with the punches, always looking at the bright side. I've also felt bad when a good friend criticized my music, which I thought was my best work.

summary:
I've been feeling really down, like a heavy cloud is constantly over me. It's more than just sadness; it's a deep sense of hopelessness and emptiness that just drains me. I also feel a lot of guilt, though I'm not always sure what for, and a general sense of worthlessness. My energy is completely gone; even simple tasks feel like climbing a mountain.

My daily life has been significantly impacted. My sleep is all over the place – sometimes I can't fall asleep at all, and other times I just want to sleep all day and still feel exhausted. My appetite has decreased, and I often skip meals because I just don't feel like eating. I've been isolating myself a lot, avoiding friends and family because I just don't have the motivation or energy to interact. It's hard to concentrate on anything, and I've noticed my memory isn't as sharp. Things I used to enjoy, like my hobbies, just don't bring me any pleasure anymore.

This started a few months ago, shortly after a significant loss in my life. It feels like a constant weight, and I've found myself just wanting to stay in bed most days. I try to push myself to do things, but it's incredibly difficult. I haven't really found any effective coping strategies yet; mostly I just try to distract myself or sleep through it. My family has noticed the changes and they're supportive, but it's hard to explain how I feel.

I know I need to stop procrastinating and get things done before something worse happens, but it's hard to follow through. I want to prepare and not leave things to the last minute. When asked about changes I want to make, I struggle to articulate them and feel I need to plan them out. A recent car accident has been very hard on me, leaving me with no money after paying for repairs. When asked about positive influences, I said it was the interviewer, because I'm talking to someone who doesn't exist, which might suggest a lack of real-life support.

summary:
Lately, I haven't been getting enough sleep, and that's a real problem for me. My weekends are mostly spent on chores, classwork, and sleeping in, which limits my social life. I also wish I could be more active and lose weight, and I have some concerns about my skin.

Emotionally, it's complicated. I wasn't really happy with my family for a long time, and while I say I'm happy with my life now, I still wish my ex-husband and I could be a family. There are so many things in my life I wish I had handled differently, almost everything, even though I try not to regret anything. I also struggle with my temper; it's something I need to work on, especially with my ex-husband where arguments can snowball out of control. Sometimes, I just don't know what to do about it, maybe just ignore him or let him be right.

I try to relax by taking naps or baths, and by trying to shift my energy to more positive things to get stuff off my mind. Money can bring me happiness, like last week when I got some, but financial problems were also a big part of why my marriage deteriorated, leading to one of the hardest decisions I've made, getting a divorce. My mom is a huge support for me; she's always been there, which is a blessing. I've also finally gotten over how kids treated me at school, which was a long-standing issue.

summary:
I haven't been formally diagnosed with depression, but I definitely know how it feels. To me, it's like being limited – like a bird trapped in a cage, a fish unable to swim, or a bird without wings. It can happen every day, sometimes in small doses. For instance, earlier today, I felt a little depressed when I was by myself.

To cope, I try to awaken and change my perspective. Focusing on colors, especially blue and green, helps a lot; painting with those colors really calms me down. Talking to people is also a big help; today, I called a friend and met up with him to feel better. Sometimes, I also smoke weed to relax.

In the past, especially in middle and high school, I'd dwell on negative thoughts, particularly if someone criticized my art. I'd feel down for a bit, but I'd eventually come out of it. Currently, I'm feeling good and have a sense of free will. Sleep isn't an issue for me at all; I can fall asleep very easily.

summary:
My depression was first diagnosed when I was 20 years old, and again three years ago. The roots of it stem from my childhood, my family of origin, the abuse I endured, and their ultimate rejection and estrangement from me. I wish I could feel better and not carry the burden of not having a family. The last time I felt truly happy was a very long time ago, before my physical illness began in 1997.

Lately, I often feel very ill and extremely fatigued. I also experience severe nightmares and nocturnal panic attacks, which are triggered by my past injury, how my family treated me, and my current physical illness and excruciating pain. This pain is from Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy, a permanent disability I got from an ER injury. My anxiety levels increase when I don't get enough sleep, making me susceptible to feeling distressed. I wish I could change my anxiety, my agoraphobia, and my PTSD symptoms, as they significantly affect my complete life.

Agoraphobia is a more recent development that's getting worse, making me feel incredibly immobilized and distressed. It's triggered by enclosed spaces, being in a car, traveling, being away from home, or anything outside my control. Despite this, I try to cope by challenging myself in small steps, reading a lot, and using bibliotherapy to inform myself, hoping to overcome it someday.

I don't have any relationship with my family now, as the rest of them are very cruel and abusive. I've found therapy to be tremendously useful; it helps with my anxiety, inspires me, helps me feel connected, and is part of my goal to give myself a voice, helping me understand and learn about myself. I stopped six months ago but plan to continue. Even with my shyness, I love human interaction and take risks to connect with people meaningfully. I wish I didn't have the constant physical pain and the symptoms of PTSD, which affect my entire life. I also struggle with insecurity, constantly trying to avoid offending or disrespecting others, which becomes an anxiety in itself.

summary:
I feel guilty about not visiting my nephew more often, especially since I moved to California, and it makes me feel bad when he gets upset when I leave. I'm also feeling a bit anxious about everything going well with my work this summer. I struggle with self-discipline, wishing I could eat healthier and not have a problem with sugar, and I still procrastinate, which I find challenging. Recently, I've been struggling to get back into my exercise routine; I was very motivated for a couple of months, but after a 10-day trip, I lost that motivation and it's been hard to regain it.

While I'm generally a good sleeper and use meditation to help, my sleep is significantly impacted when I travel for work. I don't get much time to sleep, and by the second day, I feel much more tired, find it harder to concentrate, and things just feel like more of a struggle. I also have a recurring dream about being in school, not having attended class, and knowing I'm going to fail exams, which is frustrating, even though I'm not consciously worried about failing things in my current life.

A past experience with a boss made me feel incompetent and disrespected, which led to me leaving that job. I also wish I were in a relationship. I identify as an introvert; I'm good in one-on-one situations, but in groups, I tend to be an observer and less engaged, which can be a challenge for me and might seem a little odd to others.

summary:
I was first told I was depressed in middle school, probably ten to twelve years ago, when I was in sixth grade. It's something that's reoccurred multiple times since then. A big trigger for me was Post-Katrina; I lost a lot of friends during the storm, and even though I'm getting over it, it's still there. There's just nothing positive to find in that experience.

More recently, about two years ago, I broke up with my "evil ex," and the whole thing was really bad. I was angry, and I coped by going on extreme cycling sprees, like riding for hundreds of miles in a single day, which left me in a ton of pain. It was better than overeating because I was depressed, which is something I've done. My temper is also not good; it happens frequently. In high school, I even shoved someone's head through a locker, and I've gotten into fights.

One of the biggest impacts of depression for me is the incessant need to sleep 14 hours a day. It feels unproductive, like I'm wasting too much time. While some people feel good after six hours, I need 12 hours to feel good, and my "crunch time" sleep is still seven or eight hours. I oversleep, and I don't like that part, even though I do like sleeping.

When I was in high school, after my diagnosis, they offered me help, which I just kind of took. I didn't really ask for it, but it happened. Now, I try to understand that some things just happen, and I need to carry on and move along with my life. I've learned in the past two years not to regret the things I do, but to regret the opportunities I've missed. I figure I'm still alive, so I should live and go out and do stuff, not just sit around, except when I'm reading. I don't really feel pride in the traditional sense, but I'm proud to be alive.

summary:
I've been feeling really low for months now, a heavy, persistent sadness that just won't lift. It started gradually after a significant personal loss and some stress at work. There's this overwhelming sense of hopelessness, and sometimes I just feel numb or incredibly irritable. I've lost interest in things I used to love; nothing brings me joy anymore.

My daily functioning has been severely impacted. My sleep is all over the place – sometimes I can't fall asleep or I wake up multiple times, and other times I sleep too much, struggling to get out of bed for hours. My appetite is erratic; I've either lost it completely or I overeat. I've been isolating myself, canceling plans, and finding it hard to connect with friends and family because I feel like a burden.

I have no energy, constant fatigue, body aches, and headaches. My brain feels foggy, making it hard to focus, concentrate, or make decisions. Even basic tasks like showering or getting dressed feel monumental. My work performance has suffered, and I struggle to keep up with chores. Negative thoughts and self-criticism are constant.

I try to cope by forcing myself to go for walks or listening to music, but often I just lie in bed staring at the ceiling. Talking to my therapist helps a bit, and my family is supportive, though they don't always fully understand what I'm going through.

summary:
Lately, I've still been pretty depressed, and I feel that way often. I can't remember the last time I felt truly happy. My daily life is mostly sleeping, eating, and walking my two dogs, though I don't really like spending time with them. I don't sleep well; I wake up about every two hours due to noise or needing to go to the bathroom, and I'm tired all the time. I've also experienced periods of sleeping too much and eating too much.

My living situation is tough because my neighbors harass me, so I don't come out of my apartment much. When I'm annoyed, I tend to use avoidance. I don't really have best friends, and my family closeness is ambiguous.

A specific challenge for me is hearing a person who isn't real. I talk to them, and I've even had arguments with them, like about them listening on my phone. This issue led to me being hospitalized for 15 days two months ago for depression. Before therapy, I would argue and scream at this unreal person. Now, therapy has helped me to be more cheerful and ignore things that bother me, including ignoring the person when I hear them, which isn't as hard anymore.

My past has been difficult; being homeless was very hard, and back in the 90s, I was crying all the time. Despite these struggles, my kids, especially my daughter who is graduating college and trying to do the right things, are a source of pride and a positive influence.

summary: I haven't been diagnosed with depression. Lately, I've been feeling "not great" but "not terrible," largely due to my dad's illness. I experience stress dreams, often about things out of my control, which I link to my dad's health. Despite these dreams, I find it very easy to get a good night's sleep; when I don't sleep well, I become tired, irritable, and goofy. I maintain an active life, performing in theater, auditioning, and taking classes. I have strong social connections and enjoy spending time with friends, which makes me feel happy. I'm generally friendly and open, and I cope by engaging in relaxing activities like baths, reading, and spending time with friends. I also acknowledge past traumatic experiences that cause me to feel panicky and upset when triggered, especially in certain physical situations or during criticism in acting classes. I consider myself resilient, able to take bad situations and make the best of them, and I don't dwell on past regrets.

summary:
My experience with depression is deeply tied to my sleep. It's not easy for me to get a good night's sleep; it's often really hard, and I have trouble falling asleep because my mind races, sometimes with flashbacks of bad memories. When I don't sleep well, I start to cry a lot, I get really irritable, and I feel very depressed. It makes me not feel well at all, and it's just really, really bad.

I've always felt like something was really wrong with me, even before I was diagnosed with depression. I get really nervous around people and can't really look anyone in the eye because I'm so anxious; my eyes are always kind of racing. I also get sweats in situations that remind me of past problems, so I try to avoid things that trigger those flashbacks.

Stress, a lot of everyday stress, seems to be a big trigger for me. To cope, I try to stay positive and tell myself that things will get better. I also reach out to my grandma to talk when I'm having trouble. My best friends are also a great support; they're very caring and always there to talk without judgment.

Therapy helps me a lot. Since starting, I've noticed I have fewer flashbacks and feel more relaxed. I'm trying to keep myself more occupied, and walking helps keep my mind off things. I'm proud that I'm able to acknowledge my problems and get help, unlike many people I know who deny their issues or don't seek treatment. I don't want to feel that way, so I'm glad I'm getting help for it.

summary:
I'm fine, doing alright, but still getting used to LA after moving from Maryland five weeks ago. It's overwhelming trying to find a job and meet people, even though I have a couple of friends here. The pressure is still there, but I'm slowly coming to terms with it.

I used to smoke weed to relax, but I quit. Now, I have a glass of wine and watch a movie, or go on an intense walk if I'm feeling anxious.

I'm an extrovert on the Myers Briggs test, but I consider myself extremely introverted and shy. I'm working on it.

I haven't been diagnosed with any diseases. The last time I felt really happy was over a year ago, during the writing stages of a movie I co-wrote, co-directed, and co-produced. It was pure creative energy.

I wish I was less ruled by fear and more fearless in my everyday interactions and zest for living. I also wish my parents, particularly my mom, had been more supportive when I was younger, especially during conflicts at school.

Lately, I haven't been sleeping well. I had a night where I slept for 10 and a half hours and had vivid dreams, but before that I was only getting 2 to 4 hours of sleep because I was working on set and couldn't fall asleep. I wake up tired. I stopped drinking caffeine, so without it I'm quieter and more introverted.

Leaving New York after living there for five years was a very difficult decision I had to make for money reasons. It was a very isolating time, especially because I had fallen in love with a close friend and it had gone badly, so I wasn't on speaking terms with her.

summary: I'm feeling tired lately, a combination of the gray weather in LA affecting my serotonin levels, not getting a full eight hours of sleep due to my noisy upstairs neighbor in my apartment, and my thyroid might be acting up. I also haven't been exercising as much because of the dreary weather, so I'm not as motivated. It's hard to focus and concentrate when I don't sleep well, and it takes me longer to get things done. I need eight hours of sleep, but the neighbor upstairs takes showers and does laundry late at night, and the pipes are right by my bedroom wall, which makes it hard to sleep. I'm generally a happy person and like being around people, but I can't think of anything I've done recently that I really enjoyed. I'm outgoing and people enjoy being around me, but I wish I could lose weight.

summary:
I feel "habituée," though I'm not always sure what that means. Sometimes, looking at a picture of Hawaii on my phone helps, even though it's not the real thing. I love music; singing at the Metropolitan Opera is the only thing I truly enjoy, but it's very hard. It's always been hard. I can spend 12 hours a day working on music, but it never feels like enough; there's always more I could be doing.

I don't sleep well, and I don't go out much. I'm driven to work harder to be where I want to be, to become who I want to be. I feel like I have a lot to do to reach my goals. I don't really have ways to get away from it all, not formally. I just don't feel well, the same way I always have. I want to sleep more so I can clear my mind.

summary: I've been diagnosed with depression for about ten years, since my son was born. It started when I felt like I couldn't cope with life and was just so down, like I couldn't do anything. Lately, I've been feeling grumpy, irritable, and down, mixed with anger, mostly because of everything happening with my soon-to-be ex-husband. I just keep it all inside because what else can I do? I don't get a good night's sleep; I wake up a lot, but I don't know why. I wish I did so I could fix it. I have tried therapy, but it doesn’t really help. Some therapists just stare, and others give bad advice. I wish I wasn't sad and that I was more confident. I regret giving my life over to my husband. My friends are a good influence, especially one who is always positive and upbeat, even though her life is harder than mine.

I'm generally happy and content, but I have moments where I feel really sad, overstressed, defeated, insecure, and hurt. These feelings don't really balance out with the happy ones. I spend a lot of time alone, not always by choice. I was diagnosed with depression over 10 years ago.

I tend to put the weight of the world on my shoulders and get lost in taking care of others. I carry guilt about not being there for my brother when my dad abused him, and also about not being able to support my ex-girlfriend financially. I blame myself for things I can't control.

Shopping is therapeutic for me. It makes the hurt and insecurity go away.

The gangs. Seems to be a like of snooty people here. The kind of stuck up because being from Beverly Hills or Burbank and some phonies that are really not themselves. They're imitations.
I used to, when I was with the Merchant Marines, I traveled all over the world. I've been to Australia, I've been to the road to Spain, Norway, England, Scotland. I enjoyed it. I enjoyed traveling.
What do you enjoy about traveling?
Meeting different people, meeting different cultures, speaking the language. I speak a few languages, different languages. I speak Tagalog, I speak some Japanese, speak some Thai.
I'd like to hear about one of your trips.
Well, I spent four years in Japan. I enjoyed living in Japan. The people are very friendly there. I got to climb Mount Fujiyama. That was a trip in itself to travel Mount Fuji. The food is good. I like katsudon and I like sashimi and yakitori. The cherry blossoms only comes out once a year. I just like Japan. Japan's nice.
What's one of your most memorable experiences?
My most memorable experiences?
What did you study at school?
I took engineering. I learned different things about distilling plants, diesel engines, air compressors. I went through a lot of education, a lot of schooling.
What do you do now?
I'm retired. I'm a veteran, 70-cent disability. I'm retired and I'm waiting on my SSDI right now.
What was your question?
Do you consider yourself more shy or outgoing?
Shy.
Tell me about your relationship with your family.
Oh, wow. I came from a dysfunctional family. I really don't have many family values. Me and my brother are 13 years apart in age, so I really don't know my brother that well. So I really don't know much of family life. We never sat down at the table together and had meals together. It was always like separate times. One would come in and eat, another one would come in and eat. We never sat down at the same table. So I don't know much about family life.
Sometimes when I'm feeling tense, I turn on the fish tank screensaver. Hey, I know it's not Hawaii, but it's the best I've got.
What do you do to relax?
I listen to music, and I listen to relaxation music like chimes, a brook, water running, stuff like that.
How are you controlling your temper?
I'm on medication right now. I get aggravated real easily, mood swings, personality disorder. But sometimes it just flares up depending on the situation if somebody gets in my face. But I try not to let it happen because I know the circumstances.
When was the last time you argued with someone, and what was it about?
It was on a bus. I was sitting in the back on the bus, and the guy came back and he wanted me to move so he could sit down. But I'm a big guy, and he's a big guy. So I decided just to get up and let him have the seat. I didn't want to get no confrontation. I just let it go.
Tell me about a situation that you wish you would handle differently.
That had to be meeting a girl that I've known for 18 years. She's had two children with this guy. And now the guy is going to be part of the family, and I feel very comfortable about that. But I still have feelings for this girl, but I know that the father of the boys, they're not married. He's going to be involved with the family, and I don't like that.
What's something you feel guilty about?
That's a good one. Back in 2010, I went back for my mom's funeral, and my brother was hard up for money. And he took his IRA out and spent it, and I had promised him I was going to pay him back. I wasn't able to pay him back, and he held it against me. So I felt guilty about that because I made a promise and I didn't keep it. But there was more circumstances into that, and he doesn't understand. He didn't write to me. He didn't call me. He didn't do a lot of things.
Tell me about the hardest decision you've ever had to make.
The hardest decision I ever had to make was when I was with the Merchant Marines. I was very comfortable being at sea. My wife at the time, she wanted me to stop sailing and just get a regular 9-to-5 job, where I would have been very comfortable staying at sea and working on ships. I loved that. That was what I loved. But she didn't like that, so she'd rather me work 9-to-5.
Tell me about New York or something that you wish you could erase from your memory.
Dead bodies. I always see a lot of dead bodies. I had circumstances in the military where I recovered a dead body in the Philippines. A boy had jumped ship, and we recovered the body underneath the pier. And I had to pull the body out and put it in a body bag. And another incident was in boot camp. There were circumstances where me and this guy got letters all the time from our girls. But he was engaged, and he committed suicide because the girl dumped him for another guy, and it crushed him. And he ended up jumping three feet in front of me while I was in barracks duty. And I seen his head explode like a pumpkin, and it affected me greatly. I see that all the time.
Have you ever served in the military?
Yes. I was in the Navy, 15 years, and two were the Merchant Marines.
How old were you when you joined the military?
Ah, 24.
Why did you decide to join the military?
A family thing. My father was in the Navy. My cousins was in the Air Force. My other uncle was in Marine Corps. I just wanted to serve my country.
Are you happy to do that?
Yes. I love my country, USA, serving the military. No regrets.
Did you ever see combat?
No, but we escorted Kuwaiti tankers in the Gulf. When we were in the Gulf, we had weapons pointing at us while we escorted Kuwaiti tankers in the Gulf. But I never saw combat. I was never in a combat situation. Never had to fire a gun at somebody, so I don't know what it was like.
What did you do after the military?
I was able to get a full-time job, and that was with the Merchant Marines. I went to the Coast Guard and applied for JMED. I forgot. But anyway, I worked for engineering.
How did serving in the military change you?
It made me a better person. When I first joined, I was kind of scared. But then joining the military, it made me a lot tougher and stronger. I stood up for my own grounds. I wasn't being pushed around. I just liked people applauding when you'd walk into a place and they would appreciate what you did for your country. It made it all worthwhile.
How have you been feeling lately?
Depressed. Mood swings. High anxiety. Isolation. I have no social life. I don't have much of communication with women. I don't know how to act around them. So I like to stay to myself.
Have you noticed any changes in your behavior or self-sufficiency?
I'm getting out more. Before, I was always staying in my room, but now I'm making the effort to go out to see things. I go to movies. I go out for dinner by myself. So my behavior has changed somewhat. I'm not staying in like I used to.
It's not. I have insomnia. I see dead bodies. I'm on respidone and trapezoid, which supposedly help me sleep, but sometimes I only get like three hours sleep. I'm up half the night. I don't sleep too well.
What was the question?
Yes, non-combat PTSD. It's because of circumstances that happened, trauma, while I was in the Navy. I'm going through group sessions now on Wednesday. I sit in classes and we talk about it. In fact, August 28th, I graduate from my class to get a certificate. So that's a good thing about it.
How long ago were you diagnosed?
A year ago.
What were your symptoms?
Cold sweats, nightmares, insomnia, just jittery, always looking over my shoulder. Don't feel comfortable around people. Don't trust people.
Are you triggered by something?
No.
Tell me more about that.
I'd like to change...can we change the subject?
Tell me more about that.
You're persistent.
What got you to seek help?
What brought me to seek help was I got tired of nightmares. I got tired of staying up. Got tired of being jittery. Got tired of the cold sweats. I just got tired of all those things. Being antsy and jittery and just, you know, just didn't feel comfortable.
Do you still go to therapy now?
Yes. Every Wednesday, 3 o'clock, 3 to 4.
Alright. Do you feel therapy is useful?
Yes, I do. I understand some things that I didn't understand before. And as a group, there's six of us in the group and we help each other. We give advice to each other and it works out pretty well.
Can you tell me about that?
Well, we got Marines, Navy, Army, and Air Force. And what we do, we share experiences of what we experienced. Right now we're going through a lot of problems with our daughters and relationships with the daughters that a lot of times we don't feel comfortable with our daughters because somewhere or another we have done either harm to them or something we haven't worked with them or worked out with them. And now we're trying to build that relationship up.
What sort of changes have you noticed since you've been going to therapy?
What kind of changes?
When was the last time you felt really happy?
Happy? I've never really been happy. Ali, I just live day to day, one day at a time. There has really been much happiness in my life. I've gone through a lot of ups and downs and disappointments and it's been hard for me. I've slept in homeless shelters and slept in garages and closets. So I really haven't had a kind life, you know.
Who's someone that's been a positive influence in your life?
Influence in my life? My psychologist, he's been good for me, Tim Morrissey. And my counselor I have in PTSD. It's been good for me also. I also have a friend over at the... It's been a real good friend for me. We talk a lot and I think we're good for each other. We both suffer through the same thing, bipolar and PTSD.
How are your best friends right now?
Neurotic. I'm a mess. He says I'm worse off than what I say I am. I'm just in bad shape.
Is there something you did recently that you really enjoyed?
Nice. There hasn't been any. I haven't really gone anywhere, you know. But I'm going to in September, I'm going to Philadelphia so I'm looking forward to see that. That's going to be a big thing for me going to Philadelphia, getting out of California for a while. So I'll be able to tell you more about that when I come back from Philadelphia.
What are you most proud of in your life?
A woman. I'm lonely. I'm 58 years old. Looking for some companionship. But I'm afraid to go out there and ask. Because I don't know how to act or I don't know what to say to the woman. And plus being on medication, I don't know how she's going to act on that, you know. Sometimes I over medicate myself when I take my medication. So I'm not that good of a person to be around, you know. I sleep a lot.
Okay, I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me.
You're welcome. Goodbye.
Goodbye.
Okay.
summary: Lately, I've been feeling depressed, with mood swings and high anxiety. I'm isolated and don't have a social life or much communication with women because I don't know how to act around them. I have insomnia and see dead bodies in my mind. I'm on medication, risperidone and trazodone, but I still only get about three hours of sleep. I have non-combat PTSD, diagnosed a year ago, with symptoms like cold sweats, nightmares, feeling jittery, always looking over my shoulder, and not feeling comfortable or trusting people. I sought help because I got tired of the nightmares, staying up, the cold sweats, and just feeling uneasy. I go to therapy every Wednesday and find it useful. We share experiences with other veterans, and right now we're working through problems with our daughters. I've never really been happy. I just live day to day, and there hasn't been much happiness in my life due to ups and downs and disappointments. I've even slept in homeless shelters. My psychologist, Tim Morrissey, and my PTSD counselor have been positive influences. I'm a mess, neurotic, and in bad shape. I haven't really enjoyed anything recently, but I'm looking forward to going to Philadelphia in September. I'm most proud of a woman. I'm lonely and looking for companionship, but I'm afraid to approach women because I don't know how to act or what to say, especially being on medication. Sometimes I over-medicate myself and sleep a lot, so I'm not always a good person to be around.

summary:
Lately, I've been feeling up and down, today's been a down day. I had some bad dreams last night and racing thoughts. I see signs from people who are supportive and caring, but I feel like I'm pushing them away, even though it's not a bad situation. There's an uncertainty I'm feeling, and I'm afraid I'm misconstruing my thoughts. I don't even speak on them because I feel like I'm wrong and it will change everything. It's frustrating because it's right in front of me, but I'm not looking at it. I haven't understood my behavior and thoughts since yesterday. I usually fall asleep, but I wake up late. When I don't sleep well, I'm groggy, sleep during the day, and feel more depressed and negative, but not angry negative, more of a sorrow negative.

I was diagnosed with PTSD a few weeks ago. I get triggered by things and cope by venting, turning it into jokes, writing, or meditating. Meditation has been helping, but the doctors aren't really listening, especially since the medication I'm on is messing with my mood. I need to be more assertive about it. Therapy is useful because I'm able to get more into the bond with things, understand myself better, and understand the issues of things better. The last time I felt really happy was one night when I stayed up without taking my meds, danced, and climbed trees. I had a good 24 hours. I enjoy yoga, meditation, and riding my bike. I'm not most proud of anything.
